My initial rational was that the fighting was likely to go beyond this six month mark and the situation would not resolve within this period and so some sort of state of emergency (SOE) would stay in place. Looking at things now, I think this question has been poorly thought through by GJO, since it is one where the end result will be some dull technicality.  For example: 1) The question asks: "will Ethiopia's Tigray region be under a federally-imposed state of emergency?" Not whether the one implied in the question description will be renewed. There has been more than one SOE within the region, and one is due to covid  [0]. This may be semantics, but the question is vague on this basis.  2) The question looks like it will resolve through understanding the constitutional and legal situation and points of Ethiopian technical legal detail rather than one's ability to forecast.  Article 93 of the Ethiopian Constitution cannot be taken on it own as a basis for whether the question can be resolved as it currently stands. The question is whether the non-notification of an extension means the SOE has lapsed, or whether it is still in-tact but in a legally questionable situation regarding the constitution. The counterfactual here is whether the SOE has been lifted due to Article 93 of the Constitution mandating it is after 6 months, it's not clear that has happened in Tigray either, from my research. This is a legal question, and it is doubtful whether GJO is going to launch a legal review in Ethiopia to have this tested.  Further to this,  Human Rights Watch noted that a 2016 Ethiopian SOE went "...far beyond what is permissible under international law" [1], so it's difficult to look at this on any remotely comparative basis. It looks as if in 2018 an SOE decree was already in-place before the Ethiopian Parliament voted on it [2].  For an outside view of a perhaps questionable sources questioning the constitutional aspect of the 'በትግራይ የአስቸኳይ ጊዜ አዋጅ' see [3] and [4]. 3) Finally there is the question of what federally imposed means here since the region's government has been replaced by the federal government which seems to have put in place its own state of emergency [5]. The temporary government is also directly accountable to the Federal government [6]. The federal government has recently removed all the people it put in place to run Tigray and the region will not take part in national elections scheduled for next month [7].  So the de facto governing power within Tigray is currently the federal government.  [0] https://chilot.me/2020/04/a-proclamation-to-approve-the-state-of-emergency-proclamation-no-3-2020/

Art.93 of the constitution is pretty clear: 
"A state of emergency decreed by the Council of Ministers, if approved by 
the House of Peoples’ Representatives, can remain in effect up to six 
months. The House of Peoples’ Representatives may, by a two-thirds 
majority vote, allow the state of emergency proclamation to be renewed 
every four months successively." I have no doubt that if they had the vote it would pass, but they don't seem to have had the vote yet, so technically the SOE has lapsed. Dropping my probability to 50 until I get more clarity.

The reason (Art.93(1)a "...a break down of law and order which endangers the Constitutional order and which cannot be controlled by the regular law enforcement ") for the assignment of the extra-constitutional powers to the federal government (Art.93(4)a  "...have all necessary power to protect the country's peace and sovereignty, and to maintain public security, law and order.") has not been removed yet. There is no sign that the State of Emergency Inquiry Board has made public any final recommendations in a way of a final examination of the question, whether the above mentioned reason has been removed (Art.93(6)e "To submit its views to the House of Peoples' Representatives on a request to extend the duration of the state of emergency."
There may be several reasons:
/the State of Emergency Inquiry Board could still be studying the situation in Tigray, or finalizing their report.
/a presented report could be so far undisclosed intentionally or withheld from the public by the House of Peoples' Representatives, e.g. for "national security reasons"
/the expected report could be in the process of evaluation by the House of Peoples' Representatives we haven't heard of yet
/there is a time lag between recommendation, application and approval of the first four month-extension of the federal SoE in Tigray in accordance with the constitution, depending on whether the House of Peoples' Representatives (HPR) is in session (Art.93(2)a, ...within forty-eight hours of its declaration) or not (Art.93(2), ...shall be submitted to it within fifteen days of its adoption.) The most likely time lag is thus the latter one (between adoption and approval) without immediate ability of the HPR of an approval, since there has been no news about any deliberations within 48 hours of the due date of an extension, if the same rules apply to an extension as to the initial declaration. In my view the Ethiopian constitution is somewhat unclear in this point. We'd then have to expect a declaration of an extension no later than possibly 18 May 2021, and I expect the federal SoE to be applied without interruption until then. /the last but remote possibility is that Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed is applying the federal SoE in his own interpretation of the constitution and in an unconstitutional manner. But even this would have found some attention of the media. In all, I assume the federal state of emergency is still in place and will be approved either shortly before the question's resolution or shortly thereafter, anything else would be a surprise. Initiatives such as the call for peace of the Ethiopian Orthodox church patriarch may be a sign of goodwill, but will offer no immediate relief of the tensions let alone solve the underlying problems. The most recent central government's actions, such as the designation of the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) as a terrorist group, and the replacement of the former head of interim government of the state of Tigray will not increase mutual trust needed for a solution via negotiations within less than a week. The book "algorithms" to live by inspired to have another go at setting the base rate for this question.
https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/25666050-algorithms-to-live-by
More specifically it documents the difference in forecasting approach based on the distribution of outcomes, distinguishing between normal-, powerlaw- and erlang distributed data.
Whereas i previously had (by default) assumed a normal distribution, a closer inspections learned me that the duration of the conflicts quite clearly follows a PL, in which half of the conflicts last arround a year or less and about 1/6 last 3 years or longer.
The intuition behind power-law forecasting is "the longer something has taken, the longer it will take still".
I used a quick&dirty implementation of this, looking at what percentage of conflicts lasting > 125 days end up lasting > 189 days (using 4/11/20 and 12/5/21).
This led me to a probability of 89% (compared with just 63 for the normal distribution). More interestingly, this also provides me with a way think about how probabilities of certain paths might evaporate as the deadline approaches.
In this case: if no new information appears, in 5 weeks time the probability would increase to 94%.
No changes to my forecast though :)

The crux of the question is how does Federal government benefit from a state of emergency.  From Article 93:
 (4) (a) When a state of emergency is declared, the Council of Ministers shall, in accordance with regulations it issues, have all necessary power to protect the country's peace and sovereignty, and to maintain public security, law and order.
(b) The Council of Ministers shall have the power to suspend such political and democratic rights contained in this Constitution to the extent necessary to avert the conditions that required the declaration of a state of emergency.
(c) In the exercise of its emergency powers the Council of Ministers can not, however, suspend or limit the rights provided for in Articles 1, 18, 25, and sub-articles 1 and 2 of Article 39 of this Constitution. So while a SOE does not override the right to secession (sub-article 1 of Article 39), my interpretation of the rest of Article 39 would imply that the ability to secede is virtually impossible under an SOE, so the government will have every need to continue to extend beyond the initial six months, assuming the TPLF don't just fall in line suddenly, which none of their 45 year history suggest they will. Ethiopian PM Abiy Ahmed has rejected African Union assistance on 20 Nov and ordered a military offensive to encircle the Tigrayan capital of Mekelle (500,000 people). The conflict does not seem likely to resolve in the short-term, particularly while military action is underway and aid restrictions to the region worsen the humanitarian situation. The current PM has already delayed elections (delay announced in June 2020 for August 2020 elections) with lawmaker approval due to COVID-19, which is one of the reasons that sparked the crisis. This provides a baseline for his continued control and influence over parliament through at least May or June 2021 (when the next election is currently estimated to be held). A transition of power would not occur immediately, so the chance of continued differences of opinion between the PM and the TPLF factions through 12 May 2021 (for this question) is rather high, and extension of the SOE is likely to follow.  Things that could change this might include holding earlier elections, external negotiations, yielding to international pressure or sanctions (should they arise). These alternatives seem less likely given how much the pandemic's impact has increased over time in the country, however.

This state of emergency (SOE) will still be in place on May 12, 2021, because of:
- The difficulty in capturing the 12-member Tigray executive committee 
- The refugee and humanitarian crisis in the region The difficulty in capturing the 12-member Tigray executive committee 
The immediate goal of the Ethiopian government is to capture the 12 members executive committee of the region. While the military success has thus far been weighted heavily toward the federal government, capturing the committee will be more difficult than invading and controlling the military. Capturing this group will present similar challenges to those faced by the coalition forces in Afghanistan attempting to capture Al-Qaeda leadership, as the Tigray region is mountainous and has experience fighting a war of insurgency in the 16-year civil war in the 70s and 80s. I find it unrealistic that a group that resisted for such a long time will stop resisting in 6 months, and as long as organized resistance continues I expect the SOE to continue.  The refugee and humanitarian crisis being caused by the conflict

As of now, more than 30,000 refugees from the region have fled to Sudan(more will do so each day as the fighting intensifies and approaches the Tigray Capital) and hundreds of thousands in the Tigray region were already reliant on international humanitarian aid (which has been cut off due to safety concerns for aid workers). It is unrealistic to expect the SOE to be suspended before the refugee and supply situation has been resolved, which will almost certainly not have been achieved by May
